Editor’s choice paper Non-redox metal ions promoted dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond by a ruthenium catalyst with dioxygen activation Zhanao Lv Haibin Wang Zhuqi Chen ⁎ Shuhua Zou Shuaishuai Zhu Chenlin Lou Guochuan Yin ⁎ Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage, Ministry of Education, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, PR China Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage Ministry of Education Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Dioxygen activation as the solely terminal oxidant in organic synthesis and catalytic oxidation is particularly attractive from the point of economic and environmental view. In our previous study, we have displayed that the introducing of non-redox metal ions can sharply improve the olefin epoxidation catalyzed by ruthenium complex with PhI(OAc)2 as the organic oxidation. Inspired by the successful strategy and dioxygen activation, in this study, we demonstrate an alternative protocol that adding non-redox metal ions to cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2 catalyst can remarkably improve the oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O with dioxygen as the oxidant and promote oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond whereas Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone is very sluggish. Through UV–Vis, NMR, cyclic voltammogram and EPR characterization, it has been testified that oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O can be realized under the condition of 1atm of dioxygen and 323K within 25min while extreme tough condition of 20atm of dioxygen, 343K and 8h is necessary for Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone. Combined the reaction data with characterization results, an adduct of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) is proposed as the key active species to improve the catalytic efficiency. The activity improvement in oxidative dehydrogenation illustrated a novel strategy of that adding non-redox metal ions to sluggish catalysts can remarkably improve its efficiency for dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond, especially through dioxygen as ultimate oxidant. Keywords Dehydrogenation Ruthenium complexes Dioxygen activation Mechanism study 1 Introduction Oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond to obtain the functionalized compounds has garnered significant attentions because of their chemical, biological, and pharmaceutical properties [1–3]. Traditionally, those bulky olefinic and aromatic compounds like propylene and styrene are commercially produced by heterogeneous catalysts at high temperatures with the release of hydrogen (H2), the processes of which are not suitable for various fine chemicals and pharmaceutical products [4,5]. Alternatively, the aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond under mild conditions would be a promising method with great utility in terms of atom efficiency and environmental aspects, especially when dioxygen can be conducted as the ultimate oxidant. Mizuno reported the efficient heterogeneous aerobic oxygenation and oxidative dehydrogenation of alkylarenes catalyzed by Ru(OH)x/Al2O3, however, high temperature of 373–443K was required [6]. Kanbara and co-workers reported a cyclometalated ruthenium complex, [RuCl(ppy)(tpy)][PF6], that served as an efficient catalyst for the aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation of 2-imidazoline derivatives, in which the presence of extra base is essential to promote the reaction [7–9]. Balcells and co-workers alternatively demonstrated another example of dehydrogenation of alkane including robust n-hexane or cycloalkane to n-hexene and cycloalkenes, respectively, whereas H2O2 was carried out as the oxidant [10]. In addition, Ushiyama found that the alcoholate formation step can be promoted by the “concerted activation” of an alcohol by the Lewis acid and Brφnsted bases on Ru(OH)x/support for aerobic alcohol oxidation [11–14]. Nevertheless, an efficient catalytic oxidation by dioxygen at ambient temperature for dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond is still of great demand. Recently, non-redox metal ions promoted stoichiometric and catalytic oxidations by redox metal ions have attracted considerable attentions. Understanding how these non-redox metal ions participate in oxidation events and affect the reactivity of redox-active metal ions is highly related to the mechanism of both metalloenzymes in nature [15–24] and multimetallic catalysts in chemical oxidation [25]. These findings in turn inspired chemists to explore novel catalysts for current challenges and societal demands. For instance, we observed that non-redox metal ions can positively shift the net charge of high valent metal species, which sharply benefits the electron transfer process [19,20]. Also adding non-redox metal ions can substantially manipulate the coordination structure of reactive species between dimeric and monomeric cores, thus further modulate their oxidative activities [23,24]. Remarkably, the strategy of introducing non-redox metal ions to promote the catalytic performance has been testified in versatile oxidation processes such as hydroxylation [26], C–C coupling [27] isomerization [28] and epoxidation [21,29]. Above examples deliver an alternative approach to those sluggish redox metal catalysts mediated for dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond with dioxygen. In this study, therefore, we have investigated the oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond catalyzed by Ru(bpy)2Cl2 with dioxygen as the solely terminal oxidant in the presence or absence of non-redox metal ions. The remarkable promotional effect by adding redox inactive metal ions to substantially accelerate oxidation Ru(II) to Ru(IV) was observed and the reaction mechanism in catalytic process was explored in detail, an adduct of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) was proposed as the key active species to improve the catalytic efficiency. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemical reagents were commercially available and used without further purification. Sodium trifluoromethanesulfonate (NaOTf), magnesium trifluoromethanesulfonate (Mg(OTf)2), indium trifluoromethanesulfonate (In(OTf)3), scandium trifluoromethanesulfonate (Sc(OTf)3), indoline and indole came from Aladdin. Ytterbium trifluoromethanesulfonate (Yb(OTf)3) and yttrium trifluoromethanesulfonate (Y(OTf)3) came from Accela ChemBio Co., Ltd. Other trifluoromethanesulfonates including Ca(OTf)2, Zn(OTf)2, Ce(OTf)3 and Al(OTf)3 were purchased from Shanghai DiBai Chemical Co. 2,2′-bipyridine and N,N-dimethylacetamide was purchased from Sinopharm Chemcial Reagent Co., Ltd. Ruthenium(III) chloride came from Meryer (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and quinoline came from Tianjin Heowns Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinaldine and quinaldine were purchased from Bide Pharmatech Ltd. Other substrates were purchased from either Aldrich or Alfa Aesar. 1H NMR data of 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy, Fig. S9-1, ESI, DMSO-d6): δ 7.47 (t, 2H), 7.96 (t, 2H), 8.40 (d, 2H), 8.70 (d, 2H). Ru(bpy)2(CF3SO3)2 was prepared according to the reported procedure [30]. 2.2 Reaction procedure 2.2.1 General procedure for non-redox metal ions promoted catalytic dehydrogenation by the ruthenium(II) complex In a typical experiment, 1mM ruthenium(II) complex, 2mM non-redox metal salt and 0.1M alkanes were dissolved in 2mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide in a glass tube, and then the reaction solution was magnetically stirred at 343K in the oil bath for 10h with dioxygen balloon as the oxidant source. After the reaction, the qualitative analysis was performed by GC–MS and the quantitative analysis was performed by GC using the internal standard method. Control experiments using cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2 or non-redox metal salt alone as catalyst were carried out in parallel. Reactions were performed at least in duplicate, and average data were used in the Results and discussion section. 2.2.2 General procedure for non-redox metal ions promoted catalytic dehydrogenation of 2-phenyl-2-imidazoline and 4-t-butyl-cyclohexanone by ruthenium(II) complex In a typical experiment, 4mM ruthenium(II) complex, 8mM non-redox metal salt and 0.1M alkanes were dissolved in 2mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide in autoclave (20atm O2), and then the reaction solution was magnetically stirred at 343K for 2-phenyl-2-imidazoline (363K for 4-t-butyl-cyclohexanone) in the oil bath for 20h. When 4-t-butyl-cyclohexanone was used as the substrate, the qualitative analysis was performed by GC–MS and the quantitative analysis was performed by GC using the internal standard method after the reaction. When 2-phenyl-2-imidazoline was used as the substrate, isolated yields were obtained and the products were identified with 1H NMR. Control experiments were carried out in parallel. Reactions were performed at least in duplicate, and average data were used in the Results and discussion section. 2.2.3 General procedure for non-redox metal ions promoted catalytic kinetics of aerobic oxidation by the ruthenium(II) complex In a typical experiment, 1mM cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2, 2mM non-redox metal salt and 0.1M alkanes were dissolved in 2mL of N,N-dimethylacetamide in a glass tube, and then the reaction solution was magnetically stirred at 343K in the oil bath with dioxygen balloon as the oxidant source. The product analysis was performed by GC using the internal standard method at set intervals. Control experiments using cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2 or Sc(OTf)3 alone as the catalyst were carried out in parallel and reactions were performed at least in duplicate. 2.3 Characterization equipment UV–Vis spectra were recorded on Analytik jena, specord 205. GC–MS analysis was conducted on Agilent7890A/5975C. EPR experiments were performed at 130K on Bruker A200, with Center Field of 3352.488G, Frequency of 9.395GHz, Power of 19.44mW, Modulation Amplitude of 2.00G and Receiver Gain of 1.00×103. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were collected on a Bruker AV-400 using TMS as an internal reference. Electrochemical data were collected on a CS CorrTest electrochemical workstation equipped with glassy carbon as both working and counter electrodes and saturated calomel as the reference electrode. Electrochemical measurements were performed under nitrogen in N,N-dimethylacetamide with 0.1M tetrabutylammonium perchlorate as the supporting electrolyte. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Non-redox metal ions promoted oxidative dehydrogenation by the Ru(II) catalyst with dioxygen Initial assays were performed with classic bipyridine based Ru(II) complex, cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2, which was synthesized according to the literature and hereafter referred to as Ru(bpy)2Cl2 [31,32]. 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline was first tested for aerobic oxidative dehydrogenation. As shown in Table S1, some polar solvents, including benzonitrile, acetonitrile, dimethyl sulfoxide, N,N-dimethylformamide, N,N-dimethylacetamide, exhibited better effect in dehydrogenation reaction. In all the selected solvents, N,N-dimethylacetamide is the most active solvent with 97.1% conversion and 82.7% yield due to its perfect solubility for all reactants including the catalyst and non-redox metal ions and no coordination effect to catalyst comparing to others. The influence of different temperature and ratio of catalyst to substrate have also been carefully investigated as displayed in Tables S2 and S3. The temperature of 343K was enough for 100 equiv. (with respect to catalyst) of 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline to achieve 97.1% conversion and 82.7% yield. The different concentration of Sc(OTf)3 with the ruthenium catalyst was attempted in Table S4. The sharp promotion in oxidative dehydrogenation was observed with the increasing of Sc(OTf)3/Ru(II) from 0.5 to 2. Alternatively, the efficiency was not obviously improved when this ratio was further increased to 4, indicating that 2 equiv. of Sc(OTf)3 was enough to realize the saturated promotion effect. Based on the above experiment data, the catalytic dehydrogenation in the presence of 100 equiv. (with respect to catalyst) of substrate and/or 2 equiv. of non-redox metal ion were conducted in N,N-dimethylacetamide with O2 balloon at 343K. The influence of various non-redox metal ions serving as Lewis acid on Ru(bpy)2Cl2 catalyzed dehydrogenation is summarized in Table 1 . In the absence of non-redox metal ions, the catalytic efficiency of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone is very sluggish, by which only a conversion of 22.9% and a yield of 11.5% can be obtained (Table 1, entry 1). The addition of Sc(OTf)3 lead to 97.1% conversion with 82.7% yield of quinolone under identical conditions (Table 1, entry 7). As the control group, Sc(OTf)3 alone gave only 24.8% conversion with 20.7% yield. Other non-redox metal ions, such as Ca2+, Zn2+, Al3+, and Yb3+ can also greatly promote the catalytic oxidation of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 while adding Mg2+, Ba2+ also slightly improves the efficiency. Noticeably, the promotional effect cannot be attributed to the presence of OTf− anions due to the following reasons: (1) when 6 equiv. of NaOTf was added, the concentration of OTf− is comparable amount of employing 2 equiv. of Sc(OTf)3. However only 18.1% conversion with 9.2% yield was obtained, which was similar to the result of the control experiment with Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone as catalyst. (2) The Ru(bpy)2(OTf)2 was synthesized by replacing Cl− of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 with OTf− and it displayed poor activity of 28.6% conversion and 20.4% yield (Table S4). (3) In the 1H NMR spectrum, no obvious change was observed when 6 equiv. of NaOTf was added to Ru(IV)=O compared with Ru(IV)=O in the presence of 2 equiv. of Sc(OTf)3 (vide infra). Maybe one dispute that the promotional effect originates from the potentially generated complex of Sc(III) with bpy ligand should be taken into account. Only 20.4% conversion with 13.3% yield was observed with the mixture of Sc(OTf)3 and bpy ligand as catalyst, which excluded the interaction of non-redox metal ion and ligand (Table S4). Above complimentary experiments strongly support that the promotion in oxidative dehydrogenation by dioxygen is due to the synergistic effect between the ruthenium catalyst and non-redox metal ions. The accelerated effect between ruthenium catalyst and Sc(OTf)3 was still obtained under identical conditions without any irradiation, accompanied by a conversion of 98.6% and a yield of 84.3% (Table S5). The controlled experiments clearly exclude the influence of the Ru(bpy)2Cl2 as a potential photosensitizer. Additionally, reactions under Ar with Schlenk system and air as the oxygen source were also conducted with degassed solvent (Table S6). 75.2% conversion of substrate and 64.8% yield of quinoline were observed in the presence of air, which displayed slightly less poor catalytic reactivity comparing to the reaction with dioxygen as the oxidant. In the Schlenk system, no quinoline product can be found in GC and the conversion was only 3.5%, which clearly verified dioxygen as the ultimate oxidant (Table 1). The promotional effect of non-redox metal ions on Ru(II) complexes mediated dehydrogenation was further evidenced by catalytic kinetics (Fig. 1 ). In each point compared with using the ruthenium(II) catalyst alone, the presence of Sc3+ can greatly accelerate the substrate conversion and product formations simultaneously. These results are consistent with the data in Table 1, supporting that adding non-redox metal ions promotes the catalytic dehydrogenation by dioxygen. On the other hand, neither the reaction rate nor the selectivity for the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline was affected by the addition of radical scavenger 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (Fig. S2 in the ESI), which demonstrates that free radical intermediates are not involved [6]. Catalytic dehydrogenation of other substrates also supports the promotional effect by adding non-redox metal ions (Table 2 ). Significantly, in all of the investigated substrates, using the Ru(II) catalyst alone yielded much less product than the case with the addition of Sc(III). For example, in dehydrogenation of 2-phenyl-2-imidazoline, adding Sc(OTf)3 offered 76.8% isolated yield of 2-phenylimidazole and the product was identified by 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. S6, ESI). Compared with amines, cyclic ketones have a much more robust C–H bond. Thus 4-t-butyl-cyclohexanone was selected as the substrate, for catalytic dehydrogenation reaction, and the results once again demonstrate the promotional effect by non-redox metal ions to the ruthenium catalyst. 3.2 Reaction mechanism and the interaction between ruthenium catalyst and non-redox metal ions To explore the origin of the promotional effect and reaction mechanism of dioxygen activation by Ru(bpy)2Cl2/Sc(OTf)3, characterizations of UV–Vis, EPR, cyclic voltammogram and NMR were conducted. The evidence to display their interaction and reaction pathway first comes from UV–vis studies. Due to the signals from ruthenium complexes were disturbed in the region from 190nm to 320nm by the strong UV absorption from N,N-dimethylacetamide, only signals beyond 320nm were displayed in this study. As shown in Fig. 2 and S7, Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone exhibited two characteristic absorption bands, an intense one centered at 380nm and another broad band with λmax at 565nm, which is attributed to metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) states [33–35]. Upon the addition of one atmospheric pressure of dioxygen as oxidant, the UV–vis spectrum of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 remained even after 6h (Fig. S7), indicating that the oxidation of Ru(II) under the condition of 1atm of dioxygen barely happened. This result is consistent with the reaction data that Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone was sluggish in catalytic dehydrogenation. Only under extreme tough condition of 20atm of dioxygen, 343K and 8h (Fig. 2a), the decaying of the adsorption band at 380nm and the vanishing at 565nm is observed and this change is due to the generation of high valent (bpy)2Ru(IV)=O species through oxidation by Ru(II) [29,36,37]. 1H NMR spectra (Fig. 3 ) also suggest that the oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV) cannot be observed until extreme tough condition is conducted, and the formation of Ru(IV)=O is further confirmed by EPR (vide infra). Alternatively, the oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV) by dioxygen was enormously accelerated in the presence of non-redox metal ions (Fig. 2a vs c). As shown in Fig. 2c, in the presence of 2 equiv. of Sc(OTf)3, similar oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O can be realized under the condition of 1atm of dioxygen and 323K within 25min. The promotional oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O may be attributed to influence of Sc3+ on the redox potentials of ruthenium ions, which is evidence by the negative shift of RuIV/RuIII couple in the cyclic voltammogram (Fig. S8) [7–9,38–42]. The oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond by Ru(IV)=O species was also observed and evidenced. High valent Ru(IV)=O species were generated by the in situ oxidation of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 under extreme tough condition ((bpy)2RuIV =O, 20atm of O2, 343K, 8h) or under mild conditions in the presence of Sc(OTf)3 ((bpy)2RuIV =O/Sc3+, 1atm of O2, 323K, 25min). Reaction of 10 equiv. of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline with Ru(IV)=O generated a reduced ruthenium(II) species, which possessed identical 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. 4 ) and UV–vis spectrum (Fig. 2d) of [Ru(bpy)2]2+. Fig. 4 demonstrated that the reduction of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) by the addition of substrate (1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline) lead to a mixture of Ru(II) and residual Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) adduct. Meanwhile, quinoline product can be found by GC–MS analysis, implying the catalytic circle undergoes between Ru(II) and Ru(IV)=O specie. This process was also appropriately accelerated in the presence of non-redox metal ions (Fig. 2b vs d). Inspired by our previous study, EPR was also selected to detect the reactive intermediate due to its uniquely sensitive to paramagnetic complexes [29]. It is reported that both mononuclear Ru(II) and Ru(IV) are EPR silent, while mononuclear Ru(III) center and Ru(V) complex reveal obviously characteristic EPR signals [43]. Fig. 5 show the EPR spectra changes of Ru(bpy)2Cl2 that undergoes oxidation by O2 as the oxidant in the presence of Sc3+. Some weak but distinct peaks corresponding to Ru(III) (gxx =2.60,gyy =2.40,gzz =1.66) can be observed in the oxidation process [43,44]. The Ru(III) complex can be generated by the comproportionation of Ru(IV) and Ru(II) from our previous research, and the formation of Ru(III) is more likely due to the same reaction between fresh generated Ru(IV) and the remaining Ru(II) species [29]. The trace amount of Ru(III) fades along with further oxidation, evidenced by the fact that Ru(III) signal at g=2.60 increased initially but vanished eventually after 40min (Fig. 5b). Meanwhile we synthesized RuIII(bpy)2Cl2(OTf) on purpose, and 0.3mM solution of RuIII(bpy)2Cl2(OTf) is also tested with EPR. This 0.3mM Ru(III) exhibited a much stronger signal at g=2.60, indicating that the formation of Ru(III) is trace during the oxidation of ruthenium complex by O2 in the presence of Sc3+. No characteristic EPR signals matched with Ru(V) complex could be observed in ERP spectra. The EPR experiment excluded the possibility of Ru(III) complex as the main intermediate and proposed that higher valent ruthenium complex, perhaps (bpy)2Ru(IV)=O, was responsible for our stystem. Further evidence demonstrating the interaction of non-redox metal ions and ruthenium species comes from 1H NMR spectra of Ru(IV)=O with different non-redox metal ions (Figs. 6 and S11). Origination of each 1H NMR resonance in both Ru(II) and Ru(IV) species has been carefully assigned and listed in Fig. S9 and our previous study [29]. The paramagnetic ruthenium(IV)-oxo should be six-coordinate complex along with the S=1 spin state [45–50]. The 1H NMR spectra shown in Figs. 6 and S11 displayed well-resolved signals and implied that the Ru(IV) complexes should be in the S=0 spin state with a seven-coordinate structure, perhaps as cis-[Ru(IV)=O(bpy)2Cl2] [51–54]. When Sc(III) and Al(III) were added to ruthenium complex with dioxygen as the oxidant, peaks in the region of 8.88 to 8.62ppm showed the most obvious shifts and separation as a hyperfine structure of four peaks compared to other non-redox metal ions. These resonances are assigned to four protons 4, 4′, 5, 5′ position due to their lower field and more sensitive geometric environment in high valent ruthenium complex as shown in 1H-13C HSQC spectra from our previous study [29]. The chemical shifts and peak separation were clearly displayed in the 1H NMR spectra of high valent ruthenium with different concentration of Sc(OTf)3 (Fig. S10, ESI). The interaction between non-redox metal ions and the Ru(IV)=O centers leads to the weaker deshielding effect on the magnetic anisotropy that contribute to above-mentioned shifts in 1H NMR. As mentioned above, 6 equiv. of NaOTf as additive with Ru(IV)=O was also investigated in the 1H NMR spectrum for the purpose to exclude the interaction between OTf− and ruthenium complex. As shown in Fig. 6, no obvious chemical shifts and peak separation were observed compared to in the case of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) or Ru(IV)=O/Al(III). The comparison clearly supported that the Sc(OTf)3-induced shifting in the 1H NMR spectrum was not due to the presence of OTf −. The results are also in good agreement with our catalytic dehydrogenation data and results from other characterizations. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, this work demonstrated that adding non-redox metal ions to Ru(bpy)2Cl2 catalyst with O2 can remarkably improve its dehydrogenation activity for feasible C–H bond in tetrahydroquinoline to quinoline and derivatives, imidazoline to imidazole, and for robust C–H bond in cyclic ketone to enone and phenols (Scheme 1 ); in particular, the activity improvement is Lewis acidity strength dependent on added non-redox metal ions. Through UV–Vis, NMR, cyclic voltammogram and EPR characterizations of the catalytic system, it was proposed that the presence of non-redox metal ions can remarkably accelerate the oxidation of Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O by O2 and change the redox potential of Ru(IV)=O, and an adduct of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) species is the key active species to improve the catalytic efficiency. The activity improvement in oxidative dehydrogenation illustrated a novel strategy of that adding non-redox metal ions to sluggish catalysts can remarkably improve its efficiency for dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond, especially through dioxygen as ultimate oxidant. coredata.dc:description: Dioxygen activation as the solely terminal oxidant in organic synthesis and catalytic oxidation is particularly attractive from the point of economic and environmental view. In our previous study, we have displayed that the introducing of non-redox metal ions can sharply improve the olefin epoxidation catalyzed by ruthenium complex with PhI(OAc)2 as the organic oxidation. Inspired by the successful strategy and dioxygen activation, in this study, we demonstrate an alternative protocol that adding non-redox metal ions to cis-Ru(bpy)2Cl2 catalyst can remarkably improve the oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O with dioxygen as the oxidant and promote oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond whereas Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone is very sluggish. Through UV–Vis, NMR, cyclic voltammogram and EPR characterization, it has been testified that oxidation from Ru(II) to Ru(IV)=O can be realized under the condition of 1atm of dioxygen and 323K within 25min while extreme tough condition of 20atm of dioxygen, 343K and 8h is necessary for Ru(bpy)2Cl2 alone. Combined the reaction data with characterization results, an adduct of Ru(IV)=O/Sc(III) is proposed as the key active species to improve the catalytic efficiency. The activity improvement in oxidative dehydrogenation illustrated a novel strategy of that adding non-redox metal ions to sluggish catalysts can remarkably improve its efficiency for dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond, especially through dioxygen as ultimate oxidant.
coredata.dc:title: Non-redox metal ions promoted dehydrogenation of saturated C–C bond by a ruthenium catalyst with dioxygen activation
